column2: 【v.】 fight sb. by holding them and pulling or pushing them （与某人）摔跤，扭打
column3: The two men wrestled with each other, and it was hard to tell who would win.

column2: 【n.】 [C] the final result of a discussion, war, etc. — used esp. when no one knows what it will be until it actually happens （讨论、战争等无法预知的）结果、后果
column3: People who had heard the evidence at the trial were surprised at the outcome.

column2: 【v.】(also 'tense up') make your muscles tight and stiff, or become tight and stiff 使（肌肉）绷紧；僵硬
column3: Every time the phone rang, she tensed up, being afraid to hear the bad news.

column2: 【a.】making you feel nervous and not relaxed, usu. because you are worried about what is going to happen 令人紧张的；令人不安的；令人着急的
column3: There was a tense silence as everyone waited for his reaction.

column2: 【v.】try very hard to do sth. using all your strength or ability 使劲；竭力；用尽全力
column3: She was straining to keep her head above the water.

column2: 【vt.】injure a muscle or part of your body by using it too much or making it work too hard 拉伤；扭伤
column3: I've strained a muscle in my leg and I have to go to hospital.

column2: 【n.】 [C] 腕（关节）
column3: He grasped her wrist with his free hand.

column2: 【vi.】 smile widely 露齿而笑；咧着嘴笑
column3: He walked out of the pool, grinning widely.

column2: 【n. [C] 1) (~s) [pl.] the period of your life when you are between 13 and 19 years old 青少年时期（13 到 19 岁之间的阶段）
column3: She was in her teens when she met her boyfriend who became her husband.

column2: 【n. [C] 2) (AmE, infml.) a teenager （青）少年；十几岁的孩子
column3: In real life, every teen can, and should, make their own decision.

column2: 【a.】 physically strong and good at sport 强壮的；擅长运动的
column3: I am not a brave man, nor am I athletic.

column2: 【n.】 [U] the ability to play sports or do physical activities well 运动能力
column3: Except for the second game he seemed to be in control and showed some great athleticism.

column2: 【vi.】breathe quickly in a way that can be heard because you are having difficulty breathing （由于呼吸困难而）急促吸气
column3: Brendan climbed slowly, gasping for breath.

column2: 【v.】breathe in suddenly in a way that can be heard, esp. because you are surprised or in pain （尤因惊讶或疼痛而）大声吸气，倒抽气
column3: The visitors gasped at the wonderful view.

column2: 【v.】 remember a particular fact, event, or situation from the past 回想，回忆起（某事物）
column3: Henry recalled that he first met Pollard during a business trip to Washington.

column2: 【vt.】 cut an article or picture from a newspaper, magazine, etc. （从报纸、杂志等上）剪下
column3: He showed me a cartoon clipped from a newspaper.

column2: 【n.】 [C] an article or picture that has been cut out of a newspaper or magazine 剪报
column3: He searched through piles of letters and clippings for his mother's letter.

column2: 【vt.】 draw a line under a word, sentence, etc. to show that it is important 在···之下画线（以示重要）
column3: Please underline all the noun clauses in the reading passage.

column2: 【n.】 [C] a strong hard hat that soldiers, motorcycle riders, the police, etc. wear to protect their heads 头盔；钢盔；安全帽
column3: Protective helmets must be worn on the construction site.

column2: 【vi.】 fight or struggle with sb., holding them tightly 扭打；搏斗
column3: Two men didn't stop grappling with a guard at the door until the police came.

column2: 【n.】 [C, U] 1) sth. that you do regularly and in the same way each time 惯例；老规矩；例行公事
column3: He lights his cigar after getting up every morning and this ritual has not changed for many years.

column2: 【n.】 [C, U] 2) a ceremony that is always performed in the same way, in order to mark an important religious or social occasion （为纪念重要宗教或社会事件举行的）仪式，典礼
column3: The lady of the house still performs the ritual of lighting candles at dinner.

column2: 【a.】 having or displaying a strong desire to be more successful than others 好竞争的；求胜心切的
column3: I could never play team sports 一 I lack the competitive spirit.

column2: 【n.】 [C] 手掌；掌部
【v.】 turn a part of your body around or change your position by turning 扭动（身体）
column3: He twisted his head slightly and looked up at her.

column2: 【vt.】 1) if you wrap your arms, legs, or fingers around sth., you use them to hold it （用手臂、腿或手指）围住（某物）
column3: He wrapped his arms around her, unwilling to leave.

column2: 【vt.】 2) (also 'wrap up') put paper or cloth over sth. to cover it （用纸或布）包，裹（某物）
column3: The present was beautifully wrapped in gold paper.

column2: 【n.】 [C, usu. sing.] the way you hold sth. tightly, or your ability to do this 紧握；紧抓
column3: Hold the microphone in a firm grip and keep it still.
He rested one elbow on the wall as he spoke.

column2: 【n.】 [C] (also 'indent') a cut into the surface or edge of sth. 凹口；凹陷；缺口
column3: The kid made an indentation in the center of each cookie.

column2: 【a.】 1) if clothes are itchy, they make your skin feel slightly unpleasant, so that you want to rub your skin with your nails （衣服）令人发痒的
column3: The shirt is itchy and uncomfortable.

column2: 【a.】 2) if part of your body is itchy, it feels slightly unpleasant and you want to rub it with your nails 发痒的
column3: My eyes sometimes get red and itchy in the summer.

column2: 【n.】 [C, U] failure to win or succeed 失败
column3: She was a woman who hated to admit defeat.

column2: [v.]stop resisting sb. / sth.; agree to do sth. that you do not want to do 屈服；让步
column3: He reluctantly yielded to their demands.

column2: [vt.]produce a result, answer, or piece of information 产生，得出（结果、答案或消息）
column3: Our research has only recently begun to yield important results.

column2: 【a.】 1) firmly held in a particular position and not moving or shaking 稳定的；牢固的；不摇晃的
column3: Keep the camera steady while you take a picture.

column2: 【a.】 2) developing gradually or without stopping, and not likely to change 平稳的；持续的；逐渐的
column3: The study also notes a steady drop in the number of college students taking science courses.

column2: 【ad.】 in a way that involves shaking or moving in a way you cannot control 颤抖地；抖动地
column3: I walked unsteadily to another room and looked outside.

column2: 【a.】 used to describe sth. that is surprising because you were not expecting it 想不到的；意外的；突然的
column3: The experiment with new methods produced some unexpected results.

column2: 【n.】 [C] the act of taking sb.'s right hand and shaking it, which people do when they meet or leave each other or when they have reached an agreement 握手
column3: He greeted me with a firm handshake.

column2: 【v.】 take air, liquid, etc. into your mouth by making your lips form a small hole and using the muscles of your mouth to pull it in 吸；吮；啜
column3: He sucked hard for air to keep breathing.

column2: 【vt.】 (~ oneself / sb. for) mentally or physically prepare yourself or sb. else for sth. unpleasant that is going to happen （使）准备迎接（令人不快的事）
column3: Nancy braced herself for the inevitable arguments during the meeting.

column2: 【n.】[C] the act of holding sb. close to you, esp. as a sign of love 拥抱
column3: They held each other in a tender embrace.

column2: 【v.】put your arms around sb. and hold them in a friendly or loving way 抱；拥抱
column3: The couple were sort of crying for joy and embracing each other.

column2: 【n.】 [C] 喉咙；咽喉
【n.】 [U] the state of feeling sad 悲伤；悲痛
column3: It was with great sadness that we learned of his death.

column2: 【n.】 [C] 1) a low table with a mirror where one sits while applying makeup 梳妆台
column3: Mary took the watch out of her dresser and put it on.

column2: 【n.】 [C] 2) a piece of furniture with drawers for storing clothes, sometimes with a mirror on top 衣橱
column3: He put the pants in the dresser and went to bed.

column2: 【vt.】 (slung, slung) 1) hang sth. loosely （松松垮垮地）挂，吊，悬
column3: She likes to wear a belt slung around her waist.

column2: 【vt.】 (slung, slung) 2) throw or put sth. somewhere with a careless movement and some force （随意而稍用力地）拐，掷，抛
column3: He stood up and slung his gun over his shoulder.

column2: 【a.】 bigger than usual or too big 大于一般的；太大的
column3: I'm sorry. Your parcel is a bit oversized.

column2: 【n.】 [pl.] 太阳镜；墨镜
【a.】 (only before noun) used when you want to emphasize that you mean all of a group, period of time, amount, etc. 全部的；整个的
column3: He was so tired that he slept through the entire movie.

column2: 【n. [C] 1) (AmE) a structure built onto the front or back entrance of a house, with a floor and a roof but no walls （房屋前后的）游廊，走廊；阳台
【n. [C] 2) (BrE) an entrance covered by a roof outside the front door of a house or church （房子或教堂前门外有顶的）入口，门廊
【n.】 [C] a small box made of cardboard or plastic that contains food or a drink 硬纸盒；塑料盒
column3: She was so thirsty that she drank a carton of orange juice.

column2: 【vt.】 (rewound, rewound) make a cassette tape or video go backward in order to see or hear it again 倒回（录音带或录像带）
column3: He rewound the tape and replayed a few pieces.

column2: 【v.】 drink sth. slowly, taking very small mouthfuls 小口地喝；抿；呷
column3: She was sitting at the table sipping her coffee.

column2: 【n.】 [C] (pl. patios) a flat hard area near a house, where people sit outside （房屋外面的）露台，平台
【n.】 [C] 海鸥
【n.】 [U] the railway system 铁路系统
【n.】 [C, U] a moral or legal duty to do sth. （道义或法律上的）义务，职责，责任
column3: Employers have an obligation to treat all employees equally.

column2: 【vt.】 make sb. feel calmer and less worried or frightened about a problem or situation 使安心；使放心；使消除疑虑
column3: He tried to reassure me, but I still felt anxious.

column2: 【a.】 written by hand, not printed 手写的
column3: Would you like the essay typed or handwritten?

column2: 【ad.】 without feeling ashamed of your bad behavior although other people think you should be ashamed 无耻地；不知羞耻地
column3: He shamelessly abandoned the project when he realized he would not gain any benefits from it.

column2: 【a.】 (not before noun) unable to control your behavior, speech, etc. because you have drunk too much alcohol 喝醉的
column3: David got drunk and I had to take him home and put him to bed.

column2: 【n.】 [C] a storm with thunder and lightning 雷暴
column3: Eventually, the thunderstorm stopped and we saw a beautiful rainbow in the sky.

column2: 【v.】 hold sb. / sth. very close to you with your arms around them, esp. to show that you love them （尤指表示喜爱而）抱，拥抱，搂抱
column3: Dawn and her boyfriend were cuddling on the sofa.

column2: 【a.】 1) (be ~ on / upon) be directly affected or decided by sth. else 取决于某物
column3: Your pay is dependent on how much you produce.

column2: 【a.】 2) needing sb. / sth. in order to survive or be successful 依靠的；依赖的
column3: You can't be dependent on your parents all your life.

column2: let sb. get into your car, boat, etc. and take them somewhere 搭载；接载
column3: I'll pick you up at the station and take you to the dinner party afterward.

column2: work effectively toward countering or defeating sb. / sth. 有效地对抗；击败
column3: I heard that pepper spray works well against bears.

column2: if an aircraft or spacecraft lifts off, it leaves the ground and rises into the air （飞机）起飞；（航天器）升空
column3: The aeroplane lifted off at noon for New York with more than 100 passengers.

column2: not go to bed at the time you would normally go to bed 熬夜；深夜不睡觉
column3: With so much homework to do, I will have to stay up late tonight.

column2: accept sth. even though it is not the best, or not what you really want 勉强接受；将就
column3: They want $2,500 for it, but they might settle for $2,000.

column2: near enough to walk to easily 在步行距离之内
column3: She used to live within walking distance of her children.

column2: if sth. is on your mind, you keep thinking or worrying about it 挂在心上的；惦念的
column3: He looked as though he had something on his mind.

column1: at the top of one's lungs
column2: as loudly as possible 尽量大声地；放声地
column3: He came running up to me screaming at the top of his lungs, "I love you!"

column2: lie or sit very close to sb. / sth. 偎依
column3: We cuddled up together to keep out the cold.
